subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: I hit the wrong combination of buttons for this.  I wasn t finished with the example.  If someone wants me to finish the example let me know. ...
messageBody:
I hit the wrong combination of buttons for this. I wasn't finished with the
example. If someone wants me to finish the example let me know.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
> Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 10:40 AM
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
>
>
> While that is all true, I haven't seen a need for it.
> Maybe that's due to
> my limited use of Java (a little over a year). Can you
> cite a good reason
> to use these various access modifiers? I guess I think
> in Smalltalk too
> much, where everything is "public" and the idea of
> private is only in
> comment form. I am not saying that package-protected is
> inherently bad, I
> just haven't seen a good deal of need for it. I have
> used it in some
> designs, where I wanted subclasses to override member
> variables or member
> methods, but in those cases the overriding is still
> tested through the
> parent class's public interface.
>
> Example:
>
> public abstract class AbstractParentClass{
> protected String name;
> protected String description;
> protected Schema schema;
>
> protected AbstractParentClass(Schema aSchema){
> schema = aSchema;
> }
> public Information getInformation(){
> return new Information(name, description);
> }
> protected processSchema(){
> ...
> }
> }
>
> public class ConcreteClassA{
> private Schema schema;
> }
>
> public class ConcreteClassB{
> }
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Scott Stirling [mailto:sstirling@...]
> > Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 10:23 AM
> > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> > Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
> >
> >
> > By your logic, it sounds as though one might as well do
> > away with the
> > protected keyword, as well as default package access
> > behavior. That is, you
> > are saying that if class A's methods are accessible to
> > members of its
> > package and subclasses or only its package, then what the
> > programmer should
> > do is define the methods of class A as public. You said
> > that "if the client
> > has no business touching these parts, make them private."
> > But we should say
> > that while a client can be an unknown, external process
> > or third party
> > library, a client can also be a class in the same package
> > of our own
> > library. The existence of the various access modifiers
> > gives us finer
> > control than the binary choice of public/private.
> >
> > Scott Stirling
> > JRun QA
> > Macromedia
> >
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
> > > Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 10:09 AM
> > > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> > > Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
> > >
> > >
> > > IMO...
> > >
> > > > It simply make testing easier, without changing the
> > > protection of
> > > existing code.
> > > > We find it sometimes easy to test part of a flow
> > (which usually
> > > resides in a separate method) rather than
> > > > check the public interface function.
> > >
> > > Then shouldn't these be made part of the public
> interface and
> > > allow the
> > > client to interact with them? If the client has
> no business
> > > touching these
> > > parts, make them private.
> > >
> > > > Also, I take the term "public interface" as
> relative.
> > > If an object
> > > exposes an interface (set of methods)
> > > > to its peer objects within its package, I
> see no reason
> > > not to test
> > > it, even though those methods are
> > > > package-protected.
> > >
> > > I guess I disagree here. I am not convinced that
> > > package-potected methods
> > > are part of a public interface. If they are used
> that way I
> > > would question
> > > whether some refactoring needed to take place.
> But that's
> > > just my opinion.
> > > I don't want to seem like I am picking on your
> design decisions.
> > >
> > > -Jason
> > >
> > >

> >
> >
> >
> >
>
